abstract.p: Sends four parts of Van Tieghem, and recommends Wiesner 1881.
Forgot to suggest that JL repeat experiments with bees and artifical flowers.

opener.placeName: Down, | Beckenham, Kent. | (Railway Station | Orpington. S.E.R.)

div.p: I send all 4 parts of Van Tieghem, & will you kindly return them as soon as done with, as I may wish to refer to them. Frank thinks that you wd. find very useful for all terms “Elemente der Anat. & Phys der Pflanzen” by Prof. Wiesner 1881.— It is only 276 pages in length with many excellent cuts. Frank cannot lend his copy, for it lies heavy on his conscience that he has not yet reviewed it for Nature as he promised to do.—

When you were here my brain told me that I had something to say, & you had not left 2 minutes when the confounded molecules came to their senses. It was to urge you to retry (for I think that you had tried) the Belgian’s (Plateau?) experiments with artificial flowers. I tried nearly 40 years ago, & as far as I can remember not a bee came near them. I showed them stuck in a flower garden in Staffordshire to William, who was then so young that he cd. hardly speak, & the moment he saw them, he said “Mama’s bonnet”. So I bethought me if so young a child could recognise them why not a bee. I have occasionally been much struck with bees visiting a particular species, who have flown near a flower of another kind, but of nearly the same tint, how quickly they perceived it was the wrong species & without alighting on the flowers.—

I once thought of getting (but shall never do so) an artificial flower maker to make as good a copy as he possibly could of the little Blue Lobelia for Hive-bees & of the tall blue Larkspur for Humble-bees, & then sticking them in the ground near the real flowers & watch how the bees behaved.— Any bees that came down the wind cd. not be guided by scent.— You wd. raise the bees in men’s estimation if you could show that they can distinguish by eye-sight natural from good artificial flowers,—
My dear Lubbock | Yours very sincerely | Ch. Darwin

div.note: Tieghem 1884 (see also Correspondence vol. 29, letter to Francis Darwin, 16 and 17 May 1881 and n. 6).
Francis Darwin. Elemente der Anatomie und Physiologie der Pflanzen was the first volume of Julius Wiesner’s Elemente der wissenschaftlichen Botanik (Wiesner 1881–9).
A short, unsigned review of the first volume of Wiesner 1881–9 appeared in Nature, 30 March 1882, p. 503.

Felix Plateau described his experiments with artificial flowers in Plateau 1876. See also Correspondence vol. 29, letter to John Lubbock, 3 September [1881?]. CD’s experiment using artificial flowers taken from one of Emma Darwin’s bonnets took place on 1 June 1842, and is mentioned in the notebook he used to record his observations on his children (see Correspondence vol. 4, Appendix III, p. 423). William Erasmus Darwin was born on 27 December 1839.

Hive (honey) bees (Apis mellifera) are pollinators of Lobelia erinus, while long-tongued humble (bumble) bees such as Bombus hortorum are typical pollinators of larkspur (Delphinium sp.). Lubbock did not mention such an experiment in his book, Ants, bees, and wasps, although he recorded several experiments testing the bee’s sense of colour (Lubbock 1882, pp. 291–310).
